articles.headline: Four-Day Work Week Increases Productivity 40%
articles.summary: Major trial shows employees accomplish more in less time.
articles.content: Iceland's nationwide trial found productivity increased while working 32 hours. Employee wellbeing improved dramatically. Burnout decreased 71%. Microsoft Japan reported 40% productivity boost. Work-life balance enhanced without economic loss.
articles.statementText: A four-day work week would increase overall productivity and employee wellbeing

articles.headline: Five-Day Structure Essential for Business Continuity
articles.summary: Compressed schedules create coordination and coverage problems.
articles.content: Harvard Business Review analysis shows customer service suffers with reduced schedules. International collaboration requires standard availability. Training and mentorship need consistent presence. Startups fail 30% more often with flexible schedules.
articles.statementText: A four-day work week would increase overall productivity and employee wellbeing

articles.headline: Remote Teams Outperform Office Workers in Innovation
articles.summary: Stanford study shows 13% performance increase working from home.
articles.content: Two-year study found remote workers more productive, less likely to quit. Innovation increased with diverse talent pools. Carbon emissions dropped 50%. Real estate costs eliminated. Digital collaboration tools enable seamless teamwork.
articles.statementText: Remote work is as effective as office work for team collaboration and innovation

articles.headline: In-Person Collaboration Drives 65% More Innovation
articles.summary: MIT research shows creative breakthroughs require physical proximity.
articles.content: Face-to-face interaction generates more ideas, faster problem-solving. Company culture erodes remotely. Junior employees miss mentorship opportunities. Spontaneous collaboration disappears virtually. Innovation hubs require physical presence.
articles.statementText: Remote work is as effective as office work for team collaboration and innovation

articles.headline: Optimal Work Arrangements Vary by Role and Industry
articles.content: McKinsey analysis finds hybrid models work best for knowledge workers. Manufacturing requires presence. Creative work benefits from flexibility. Individual preferences and job requirements should guide policy. Context determines optimal arrangement.
